Core Server (chungoidmcp.py)

Main MCP Server implementation for Chungoid Bootstrapper.

Handler for the ‘initialize_project’ tool. Copies templates to the specified directory.

On success, also sets the target directory context for the current session.

Stage Executor (stage_executor.py)

Handles the execution of individual project stages.

class stage_executor.DecisionFramework(*args, **kwargs)[source]

Bases: object

decide(*args, **kwargs)[source]
exception stage_executor.StageExecutionError(message: str, details: Any | None = None)[source]

Bases: Exception

Custom exception for errors during stage execution.

class stage_executor.StageExecutor(state_manager: StateManager, decision_logic_config: Dict[str, Any], project_root_dir: str | Path, reflections_summary: str, server_stages_dir: str, common_template_path: str)[source]

Bases: object

Orchestrates the execution of a single project stage.

Reads prompts, interacts with tools (via adapters or direct calls), makes decisions (via framework), and manages state updates.

async execute_next_stage_async() → Dict[str, Any][source]

Determines the next stage and executes its logic asynchronously.

Returns:

A dictionary indicating the status and result of the execution attempt. Includes keys like ‘status’, ‘message’, ‘stage_executed’, ‘result’.

request_status_update(confirmed_stage: int | float, confirmed_status: str, artifacts: list[str], reason: str | None = None) → bool[source]

Public method to request a status update from the StateManager.

This should typically be called by the main server loop after receiving user confirmation or post-execution analysis.

Parameters:

  • confirmed_stage – The stage number that was executed.

  • confirmed_status – The final status (‘DONE’, ‘FAIL’, ‘PASS’).

  • artifacts – List of artifacts generated by the stage.

  • reason – Optional reason for failure.

Returns:

Boolean result from StateManager.update_status.

Utilities (utils)

State Manager (utils.state_manager)

Manages the project status file (project_status.json) with file locking.

exception utils.state_manager.StatusFileError[source]

Bases: Exception

Custom exception for errors related to status file operations.

class utils.state_manager.DummyFileLock[source]

Bases: object

A dummy lock object that does nothing, for testing or when locking is disabled.

acquire(timeout=None)[source]
release()[source]
class utils.state_manager.StateManager(target_directory: str, server_stages_dir: str, use_locking: bool = True)[source]

Bases: object

Handles reading, updating, and validating the project status file.

Uses file locking to prevent race conditions during updates.

get_last_status() → Dict[str, Any] | None[source]

Gets the status entry for the highest stage in the latest run.

Finds the run with the highest run_id and returns the last status update within that run’s status_updates list.

Returns:

The last status dictionary from the latest run, or None if no runs or statuses exist.

get_full_status() → Dict[str, List[Dict[str, Any]]][source]

Gets the entire status structure (including all runs).

Returns:

[…] }.

Return type:

The full status dictionary { ‘runs’

Raises:

StatusFileError – If the status file cannot be read or parsed.

get_next_stage() → int | float | None[source]

Determines the next stage to be executed based on the latest run.

Logic: - Reads the status file and finds the latest run. - Finds the highest stage number marked as DONE or PASS in that run. - Lists available stage definition files (stage*.yaml) in server_stages_dir. - Returns the lowest available stage number greater than the highest completed stage. - Returns 0 if no runs or no completed stages exist in the latest run.

Returns:

The next stage number (int or float), or None if an error occurs.

update_status(stage: int | float, status: str, artifacts: List[str], reason: str | None = None) → bool[source]

Updates the status file by adding a new entry to the latest run.

Creates the first run (run_id: 0) if no runs exist. Validates input status. Adds a timestamp to the new entry. Writes the updated list back to the file.

Parameters:

  • stage – The stage number (e.g., 1.0, 2).

  • status – The result status (e.g., “PASS”, “FAIL”, “DONE”).

  • artifacts – A list of relative paths to generated artifacts.

  • reason – Optional reason, e.g., for FAIL status.

Returns:

True if the update was successful, False otherwise.

store_artifact_context_in_chroma(stage_number: float, rel_path: str, content: str, artifact_type: str = 'unknown') → bool[source]

Stores a single artifact’s content and metadata in ChromaDB synchronously.

Retrieves artifact context from ChromaDB based on a semantic query (synchronous).

Retrieves relevant reflections from ChromaDB based on a semantic query (synchronous).

Chroma Utilities (utils.chroma_utils)

Utilities for interacting with ChromaDB for context storage.

utils.chroma_utils.get_chroma_client() → ClientAPI | None[source]

Provides a singleton ChromaDB client instance based on configuration.

Reads configuration using utils.config_loader.

Returns:

An initialized ChromaDB client (HttpClient or PersistentClient) or None if config fails.

async utils.chroma_utils.get_or_create_collection(collection_name: str) → Collection | None[source]

Helper to get or create a collection, returning the collection object or None.

Adds multiple documents to a specified Chroma collection.

Analysis Utilities (utils.analysis_utils)

Utilities for running static analysis tools like Ruff and Bandit.

Runs Ruff on a file/directory and returns PASS/FAIL and issues.

utils.logger_setup.setup_logging()[source]

Configures root logger based on settings from config.yaml or defaults.

Reads logging configuration (level, format, file, max_bytes, backup_count) from the loaded configuration.

# Args: # <<< Remove Args if parameters are removed, or update if kept >>> # max_bytes: Maximum size of the log file before rotation. # backup_count: Number of backup log files to keep.
